name: Kimchi Nabe
description: Cure your winter blues with a steamy pot of Japanese Kimchi Nabe. Made with anchovy broth, kimchi, pork belly, and vegetables, this soup pot is hot and sour with a good kick of spice that warms you right up!

video.name: How To Make Kimchi Nabe (Recipe) キムチ鍋の作り方（レシピ）
video.description:
Warm up with this spicy and flavorful Japanese Kimchi Nabe made with anchovy broth, kimchi, pork belly, and vegetables.

PRINT RECIPE ▶ http://www.justonecookbook.com/kimchi...

Ingredients:

1 lb. (500 g) napa cabbage kimchi, cut if necessary
Handful bean sprouts
½ large onion
½ to 1 pack medium firm tofu
5-6 napa cabbage leaves
1 Tokyo negi (or 3 green onions/scallions)
⅓ carrot
3 stalks garlic chives, Asian/Chinese chives, or Nira (different from chives used for garnish)
1 pack enoki mushrooms
.8 lb (400 g) thinly sliced pork belly or pork loin
1 Tbsp. sesame oil
4 cups (960 ml) dashi (ingredients & recipe below) or chicken broth

Seasonings

1 Tbsp. sake
1 Tbsp. gochujang
1 tsp. gochugaru (Korean pepper flakes)
1 Tbsp. sugar
4 Tbsp. (60 ml) Kimchi juice
1 Tbsp. soy sauce
1 Tbsp. miso (I use awase miso)
½ tsp. kosher salt (1/4 tsp. table salt)

For Dashi

¼ cup (12 g) iriko (dried baby sardines/anchovies)
.4 oz (12 g) kombu (about 3x4")
4 cups (960 ml) water

Instructions ▶ http://www.justonecookbook.com/kimchi...

★ FOLLOW JUST ONE COOKBOOK ★ 

WEBSITE :: http://www.justonecookbook.com
FACEBOOK :: http://www.facebook.com/justonecookbook

INSTAGRAM :: http://instagram.com/justonecookbook


★ INGREDIENTS & COOKING EQUIPMENT ★

CUTTING BOARD :: http://www.cuttingboard.com
DONABE (SIMILAR) :: http://amzn.to/1ocBXyI
MEASURING CUP :: http://amzn.to/20ivC1W
KNIFE :: http://amzn.to/1WNpYCR


★ MUSIC ★

♫ "Whale Of A Time 4" :: http://www.audionetwork.com/browse/m/...

♫ "Happy As Larry 3" :: http://www.audionetwork.com/browse/m/...

LIGHTS :: http://amzn.to/1I84kEk
SOFTWARE :: Adobe Premiere

recipeIngredient: 1  Tokyo negi (naga negi; long green onion) ((or 3 green onions/scallions))
3 stalks garlic chives (Chinese chives or Nira)
4 cups dashi (Japanese soup stock) ((see recipe below; or use chicken broth))
¼ cup iriko/niboshi (boiled and dried anchovies)
⅓ oz kombu (dried kelp) ((about 3 x 4 inches, 7.6 x 10 cm per ⅓ oz))
1 Tbsp miso ((you can use any type of miso))
½ tsp Diamond Crystal kosher salt

itemListElement.text: This is an extra step and not everyone follows this method, but I highly recommend removing the head and guts from the anchovies to reduce the bitter flavor in dashi (watch how I do it in this video).
itemListElement.name: This is an extra step and not everyone follows this method, but I highly recommend removing the head and guts from the anchovies to reduce the bitter flavor in dashi (watch how I do it in this video).

itemListElement.text: Gently clean ⅓ oz kombu (dried kelp) with a damp cloth (but don‘t wipe off the white powder—that‘s umami!) In a small saucepan, put 4 cups water, the kombu, and ¼ cup iriko/niboshi (boiled and dried anchovies).
itemListElement.name: Gently clean ⅓ oz kombu (dried kelp) with a damp cloth (but don‘t wipe off the white powder—that‘s umami!) In a small saucepan, put 4 cups water, the kombu, and ¼ cup iriko/niboshi (boiled and dried anchovies).

itemListElement.text: Bring it to boil on low heat. It’s best to slowly infuse the water with the kombu and anchovies. Once boiling, cover and keep on low heat and simmer for 10 minutes.
itemListElement.name: Bring it to boil on low heat. It’s best to slowly infuse the water with the kombu and anchovies. Once boiling, cover and keep on low heat and simmer for 10 minutes.

itemListElement.text: Once you are done simmering the dashi, strain through a fine sieve. Set aside the dashi. Tip: With the spent kombu and anchovies, you can make candied anchovies and simmered kombu.
itemListElement.name: Once you are done simmering the dashi, strain through a fine sieve. Set aside the dashi. Tip: With the spent kombu and anchovies, you can make candied anchovies and simmered kombu.

itemListElement.text: Meanwhile, start prepping the ingredients. Thinly slice ½ onion. Cut 14 oz medium-firm tofu (momen dofu) into small blocks.
itemListElement.name: Meanwhile, start prepping the ingredients. Thinly slice ½ onion. Cut 14 oz medium-firm tofu (momen dofu) into small blocks.

itemListElement.text: Cut 6 leaves napa cabbage into 2-inch (5-cm) pieces widthwise (start cutting from the bottom toward the leafy side). The bottom part of napa cabbage is thicker, so cut these pieces into smaller pieces lengthwise (see how I do it in the video).
itemListElement.name: Cut 6 leaves napa cabbage into 2-inch (5-cm) pieces widthwise (start cutting from the bottom toward the leafy side). The bottom part of napa cabbage is thicker, so cut these pieces into smaller pieces lengthwise (see how I do it in the video).

itemListElement.text: Slice 1 Tokyo negi (naga negi; long green onion) diagonally into ½-inch (1.3-cm) pieces and slice ⅓ carrot diagonally into ¼-inch (0.6-mm) slices.
itemListElement.name: Slice 1 Tokyo negi (naga negi; long green onion) diagonally into ½-inch (1.3-cm) pieces and slice ⅓ carrot diagonally into ¼-inch (0.6-mm) slices.

itemListElement.text: Cut 3 stalks garlic chives (Chinese chives or Nira) into 2-inch (5-cm) pieces. Discard the bottom of 7 oz enoki mushrooms and loosen them up.
itemListElement.name: Cut 3 stalks garlic chives (Chinese chives or Nira) into 2-inch (5-cm) pieces. Discard the bottom of 7 oz enoki mushrooms and loosen them up.

itemListElement.text: Rinse 6 oz bean sprouts and place all the vegetable ingredients on a plate. Cut 13 oz sliced pork belly into 2-inch (5-cm) pieces and set aside.
itemListElement.name: Rinse 6 oz bean sprouts and place all the vegetable ingredients on a plate. Cut 13 oz sliced pork belly into 2-inch (5-cm) pieces and set aside.

itemListElement.text: In a large donabe (4–5 serving) or pot (use two donabe or pots if doubling the recipe), heat 1 Tbsp toasted sesame oil over medium-low heat and add the sliced pork belly. Stir-fry the meat until no longer pink.
itemListElement.name: In a large donabe (4–5 serving) or pot (use two donabe or pots if doubling the recipe), heat 1 Tbsp toasted sesame oil over medium-low heat and add the sliced pork belly. Stir-fry the meat until no longer pink.

itemListElement.text: Add 1 lb kimchi and onion and stir-fry for 5 minutes.
itemListElement.name: Add 1 lb kimchi and onion and stir-fry for 5 minutes.

itemListElement.text: Then add 1 Tbsp sake and 1 Tbsp gochujang (Korean chili paste).
itemListElement.name: Then add 1 Tbsp sake and 1 Tbsp gochujang (Korean chili paste).

itemListElement.text: Add 1 tsp gochugaru (Korean pepper flakes) and 1 Tbsp sugar and mix it all together.
itemListElement.name: Add 1 tsp gochugaru (Korean pepper flakes) and 1 Tbsp sugar and mix it all together.

itemListElement.text: Add 4 Tbsp kimchi juice and 4 cups dashi (Japanese soup stock) and make sure it’s mixed evenly.
itemListElement.name: Add 4 Tbsp kimchi juice and 4 cups dashi (Japanese soup stock) and make sure it’s mixed evenly.

itemListElement.text: Cover and bring to boil. Once boiling, reduce heat to low and cook for 5 minutes.
itemListElement.name: Cover and bring to boil. Once boiling, reduce heat to low and cook for 5 minutes.

itemListElement.text: Add 1 Tbsp soy sauce and 1 Tbsp miso. Mix all together and make sure the miso is completely dissolved.
itemListElement.name: Add 1 Tbsp soy sauce and 1 Tbsp miso. Mix all together and make sure the miso is completely dissolved.

itemListElement.text: Add the rest of ingredients and cover to cook on medium heat for 10 minutes, or until all the ingredients are tender.
itemListElement.name: Add the rest of ingredients and cover to cook on medium heat for 10 minutes, or until all the ingredients are tender.

itemListElement.text: Taste the soup and add ½ tsp Diamond Crystal kosher salt if necessary (I added about ½ tsp). Each miso has different saltiness, so you really need to taste the soup to adjust the flavor.
itemListElement.name: Taste the soup and add ½ tsp Diamond Crystal kosher salt if necessary (I added about ½ tsp). Each miso has different saltiness, so you really need to taste the soup to adjust the flavor.

itemListElement.text: You can keep the leftovers in an airtight container and store in the refrigerator for 3 days.
itemListElement.name: You can keep the leftovers in an airtight container and store in the refrigerator for 3 days.

review.reviewBody: Delicious! I love kimchi jjigae, but now I also love kimchi nabe. My family likes the nabe better as it not as funky as the original.

So very tasty! I used what I had.... leftover homemade dashi, no sprouts, I think it's a forgiving recipe so long as you have good kimchi to build around. Taste as you go - much depends on the heat and saltiness of your kimchi - I did not need to add the gochugaru or extra salt - it was plenty hot and savoury for me without.

I like this recipe a lot, but 1 tbsp sugar for me is way too much. It completely removed the sharpness of the kimchi and I had to try to mask the sweetness by adding vinegar. I think next time 1 tsp would be enough.

This recipe was so delicious! My partner said it is the best hot pot I have made so far. The flavors were just so yummy. I put in soba noodles at the end to finish up the broth and it made it extra filling.
